thread.title_full: Spending the night in New York City is getting cheaper - MarketWatch

author: By     Lisa Fickenscher
title: Spending the night in New York City is getting cheaper
text:
Shutterstock Tourists are getting a great bargain these days when they book a hotel room in the Big Apple.
New York City hotels have long been known as the most expensive in the U.S., but that’s changing as a glut of new properties open their doors and drive prices down.
Among the top 25 markets, including Atlanta, San Francisco and Orlando, New York was the only city to experience a decrease in the average daily room rate — a standard measure of hotel performance, according to hotel research firm STR, which released industry second-quarter results compared with the same period last year.
The average hotel rate in the city is down 1.5% to $269, though occupancy rates continue to be the highest in the country at 89%. San Francisco, by contrast, has an occupancy rate of 87.5%, but its room rates grew by nearly 9% to $219 in the second quarter.
“It doesn’t make sense that hotel rooms are full in New York and rates are down,” said STR’s senior vice president, Jan Freitag. “The hotels don’t have pricing power.”
“Tourism is only getting better, but there are a lot of new hotels and Airbnb is a factor … continuing to put pressure on rates,” said hotelier Richard Born, who operates the Maritime, Mercer and Pod hotels, among others.
The first quarter (normally a slow time) was worse, however, down 4.1% to $204 per night.
There are more than 14,000 hotel rooms under development in New York, mostly budget-oriented properties. In total, the city has about 105,000 hotel rooms.
There is no shortage of tourists coming here either. The city attracted a record 54.6 million tourists last year and estimates that 58.1 million will arrive this year.
This report first appeared on NYPost.com
